On Monday 31 October 2005 14:29, Elliotte Harold wrote:
> David Saff wrote:
> > To me, the effort to go from this:
> >
> > private void foo()
> >
> > to this:
> >
> > /** internal: may change */
> >
> > protected void foo()
>
> Wow that's scary, but I guess it is Halloween. :-) You're right. It's
> very little effort, but it's made the API worse, not better. First of
> all it's more complex and requires more effort to understand. Second,
> it's taken a stable, reliable class and turned it into quicksand. There
> are now pieces of it that used to be completely invisible that
> developers now have to think about avoiding.
>
> If the method is internal and may change why expose it to the class's
> clients? Why suggest they use it at all? If it can be private, then make
> it so. The only reason I can possibly see for doing this is if it were
> somehow important for JUnit's own classes to override or invoke this
> method, but clients were not meant to. Even so, I'd try real hard to
> make it package protected or private instead.

What would you choose to do about an extension point that should
only be used by people who know what they're doing? You have to
/offer/ it as an extension point - eg declare a method as `protected` -
but that doesn't [have to] mean it's open for all comers.

`internal` means `use at your own risk`. I know you conflate
visibility with publication status, and I understand why, but I
don't think it's anywhere as critical/fragile as you do.
